name: Blade Runner, 1982 Japanese B2 poster (20x29in aprox.) Original Vintage Movie Poster
description:
Poster for the first release of the movie in Japanese theaters.


Grade: A+ (see below)
Important: In order to take the pictures of the posters, we are fixing them to a white board using magnets, NOT PINS.



About Grading
Like in any object that has aged over time, grading and relative conditions of a poster are essential to consider prior to purchase. Having said that, the conventional grading system (good, very good, fine...) for posters can often be confusing as a poster never really sits fixed in a particular state over a long period of time. Variables such as how a poster is stored, the environment in which it is stored in and how the poster is treated; linen-back vs non linen back can greatly affect the value of a poster.

The grading system we have chosen to use is an Alphabetical system widely used by major auction houses to describe the condition of our posters.

A Posters are in excellent condition. Artwork is undamaged, posters may present minor separations and/or restoration along fold lines. The poster may also (but not always) show tiny tears or pinholes along the border.

B Posters may present minor paper loss, not only along the folds. When mounted on linen all those areas may have had restoration work done.

C Posters may present noticeable paper loss. Artwork may show fading and/or restoration.

Sometimes a plus (+) or a minus (-) sign is placed near the grade in order to emphasize the specific aspects of that particular value.

i.e. A+ indicates that you should expect a poster with totally undamaged artwork, no separation along the folds and no signs of restoration work.

name: One Million Years B.C. R-1970s Spanish One Sheet (27x40in. aprox)
description:
Poster for the re-release of the movie in Spanish theatres at some point in the 70s. Linen Backed. Ships Rolled

Grade: A+ (see below)

What is Linen-Backing? (and Paper-Backing)
Linen Backing is a process of stabilizing the acidity of the paper gluing it with wheat paste to acid free paper and light cotton or linen canvas. Linen backing helps preserve the poster and is also used by professional restorers to repair posters and return them as close as possible to their original condition. A similar process occurs when mounting posters on acid-free paper, where paper is used instead of canvas.

Window Cards were used in restaurants, cafes and many other places other than cinemas. They usually have a white space on the top area used to advertise day and time of the projection. The white space in this lobby card is unused. Ships in a flat package
Grade: A+ (see below)
Important: In order to take the pictures of the posters, we are fixing them to a white board using magnets, NOT PINS. 

About Grading
Like in any object that has aged over time, grading and relative conditions of a poster are essential to consider prior to purchase. Having said that, the conventional grading system (good, very good, fine...) for posters can often be confusing as a poster never really sits fixed in a particular state over a long period of time. Variables such as how a poster is stored, the environment in which it is stored in and how the poster is treated; linen-back vs non linen back can greatly affect the value of a poster.

The grading system we have chosen to use is an Alphabetical system widely used by major auction houses to describe the condition of our posters.

A Posters are in excellent condition. Artwork is undamaged, posters may present minor separations and/or restoration along fold lines. The poster may also (but not always) show tiny tears or pinholes along the border.

B Posters may present minor paper loss, not only along the folds. When mounted on linen all those areas may have had restoration work done.

C Posters may present noticeable paper loss. Artwork may show fading and/or restoration.

Sometimes a plus (+) or a minus (-) sign is placed near the grade in order to emphasize the specific aspects of that particular value.

i.e. A+ indicates that you should expect a poster with totally undamaged artwork, no separation along the folds and no signs of restoration work.

name: Anatomy of a Murder,US Window Card (14x22in), Paper-Backed 1959 Original Vintage Movie Poster

Grade: A (see below)

Important: In order to take the pictures of the posters, we are fixing them to a white board using magnets, NOT PINS. 

What is Linen-Backing? (and Paper-Backing)
Linen Backing is a process of stabilizing the acidity of the paper gluing it with wheat paste to acid free paper and light cotton or linen canvas. Linen backing helps preserve the poster and is also used by professional restorers to repair posters and return them as close as possible to their original condition. A similar process occurs when mounting posters on acid-free paper, where paper is used instead of canvas.

Poster for the first release of the movie in Japanese theaters. Ships Rolled.

Grade: A+ (see below)
Important: In order to take the pictures of the posters, we are fixing them to a white board using magnets, NOT PINS.

About Grading
Like in any object that has aged over time, grading and relative conditions of a poster are essential to consider prior to purchase. Having said that, the conventional grading system (good, very good, fine...) for posters can often be confusing as a poster never really sits fixed in a particular state over a long period of time. Variables such as how a poster is stored, the environment in which it is stored in and how the poster is treated; linen-back vs non linen back can greatly affect the value of a poster.

The grading system we have chosen to use is an Alphabetical system widely used by major auction houses to describe the condition of our posters.

A Posters are in excellent condition. Artwork is undamaged, posters may present minor separations and/or restoration along fold lines. The poster may also (but not always) show tiny tears or pinholes along the border.

B Posters may present minor paper loss, not only along the folds. When mounted on linen all those areas may have had restoration work done.

C Posters may present noticeable paper loss. Artwork may show fading and/or restoration.

Sometimes a plus (+) or a minus (-) sign is placed near the grade in order to emphasize the specific aspects of that particular value.

i.e. A+ indicates that you should expect a poster with totally undamaged artwork, no separation along the folds and no signs of restoration work.

name: The Goonies, US One Sheet (24x42in) Style B. Linen Backed. 1985 Original Vintage Movie Poster
description:
Style B poster for the first release of the movies in US Theatres in 1985. Linen Backed.

Grade: A+ (see below)

What is Linen-Backing? (and Paper-Backing)

Linen Backing is a process of stabilizing the acidity of the paper gluing it with wheat paste to acid free paper and light cotton or linen canvas. Linen backing helps preserve the poster and is also used by professional restorers to repair posters and return them as close as possible to their original condition. A similar process occurs when mounting posters on acid-free paper, where paper is used instead of canvas.
